messageBody:
--- In junit@y..., "korosh_afshar" <korosh_afshar@y...> wrote:
> It seems that depending on the number of unit test methods in my
> TestCase, the constructor is called that many times.
>
> Is this because of the way junit framework is setup?
>
> Does the framework create mutiple test case objects
> *under the hood* depending on the number of testXXXXX()
> methods that I have and then run the test method for each
> one of these objects?

yup. if you look at the "test infected" article that comes with
the JUnit distribution, you can see the "static" way of building
up a TestSuite...when you create a TestSuite reflectively, e.g.

TestSuite suite = new TestSuite( MyTest.class );

it's basically doing all that work for you: constructing a new
MyTest for every testXXX() method in MyTest, whose name is the
same as the name of the test method. each of these relies on
TestCase's runTest() behavior--reflectively invoke the test method
on the instance.
